oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Pushmataha
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Portrait paintings; Military uniforms
Indians of North America -- Biography; Indians of North America -- Portraits; Indians of North America -- History
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Portrait of Choctaw chief Pushmataha shown wearing a military uniform of the U. S. Army.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: McKenney, Thomas Loraine, 1785-1859; Hall, James, 1793-1868
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: History of the Indian tribes of North America, with biographical sketches and anecdotes of the principal chiefs.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Pushmataha (circa 1764-1824) was one of the most renown leaders of the Choctaw people. He grew up near Fort St. Stephens, a trading post located in present-day Alabama and acquired a leadership role early in his life. In the early 1800s, Pushmataha emerge; d as a spokesman for the Choctaws in negotiations with the U. S. government. At the outbreak of the Creek War (1813-1814), he was largely responsible for maintaining peaceful relations with the Americans while instigating attacks on the Creek Indians.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Tennessee State Library & Archives
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Tustennuggee Emathla or Jim Boy
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Portrait paintings
Indians of North America -- Biography; Indians of North America -- Portraits; Indians of North America -- History
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Portrait of Creek Chief Tustennuggee Emathla in colorful Native-American wear.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: McKenney, Thomas Loraine, 1785-1859; Hall, James, 1793-1868
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: History of the Indian tribes of North America, with biographical sketches and anecdotes of the principal chiefs.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Tustennuggee was a full-blooded Creek born around 1793 near the Tallapoosa River. The name Tustennuggee means "warrior" and Emathla means "next to the warrior," but he was also referred to by the more familiar name of Jim Boy.; During the Creek wars, he aligned himself with the Americans. He was also involved in battles against the Seminoles.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Tennessee Historical Society
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Menawa
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Portrait paintings
Indians of North America -- Biography; Indians of North America -- Portraits; Indians of North America -- History
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Portrait of Creek warrior Menawa in colorful Native-American clothing and a beaded bag.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: McKenney, Thomas Loraine, 1785-1859; Hall, James, 1793-1868
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: History of the Indian tribes of North America, with biographical sketches and anecdotes of the principal chiefs.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Menawa was a half-blooded Creek warrior who supported the British during the War of 1812 and opposed the cession of tribal lands to the white people. He fought in support of the United States during the Seminole War, but was later forced; to move west during the removal to Indian territory from 1836-1840. Menawa was also known as "Crazy War Hunter" because of his daring exploits during battle.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Tennessee Historical Society
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Selocta
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Portrait paintings
Indians of North America -- Biography; Indians of North America -- Portraits; Indians of North America -- History
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Portrait of Creek chief Selocta in colorful Native-American clothing and peace medal.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: McKenney, Thomas Loraine, 1785-1859; Hall, James, 1793-1868
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: History of the Indian tribes of North America, with biographical sketches and anecdotes of the principal chiefs.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Selocta was a Creek leader who allied himself with the United States during the War of 1812. Selocta's father, Chinnaby, was an important chief to many of the Creek people. When General Andrew Jackson advanced upon their territory,; he was met by Selocta, who fought as an ally next to the future United States president as they both battled the British. Despite Selocta's loyalty, he was later forced to relocate to the west.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Tennessee Historical Society
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Spring Frog
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Portrait paintings
Indians of North America -- Biography; Indians of North America -- Portraits; Indians of North America -- History
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Portrait of Cherokee chief "Spring Frog" in colorful Native-American clothing.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: McKenney, Thomas Loraine, 1785-1859; Hall, James, 1793-1868
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: History of the Indian tribes of North America, with biographical sketches and anecdotes of the principal chiefs.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: "Tooan Tuh," or Spring Frog, was a Cherokee born near Lookout Mountain in 1754 in the state of Tennessee. He was a skilled trapper, hunter, and ball player. He served under General Jackson during the campaign against the Creeks.; He later moved to the country that was assigned to the Cherokees west of Arkansas.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Tennessee Historical Society

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Oche Finceco
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Portrait drawings; Portrait prints; Indian agents; Book illustrations
Indians of North America-- Biography; Indians of North America-- Portraits; Indians of North America-- History
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Color lithograph image, with very wide margins on large folio. Detailed rendering of a Native American with black hair, dark brown skin, ruffled white collar,; and blue tunic with red fringes.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: McKenney, Thomas Loraine, 1785-1859; Hall, James, 1793-1868
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: History of the Indian tribes of North America, with biographical sketches and anecdotes of the principal chiefs.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Oche-Finceco, called Charles Cornells, a Creek half breed. He was one of the delegation to Washington in 1826, and also signed the treaty. Nothing remarkable is known of Cornells, except that he was followed by certain swindlers, who won the money he; received at the Treaty of Washington ($10,000) whereupon, he went into his loft and hung himself. He was held in much esteem by his people, who were engaged, when McKenney was in their country, in 1827, in building a roof of split shingles over his grave
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Tennessee Historical Society
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: Daniel Rice and James G. Clark

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Ledagie
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Portrait drawings; Portrait prints; Indian agents; Book illustrations
Indians of North America-- Biography; Indians of North America-- Portraits; Indians of North America-- History; Creek Indians
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A half-length portrait, facing right, wearing a plumed hat.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: McKenney, Thomas Loraine, 1785-1859; Hall, James, 1793-1868
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: History of the Indian tribes of North America, with biographical sketches and anecdotes of the principal chiefs.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: An Upper Creek Chief, who was later associated with the Trading Post at Jacksonville, Alabama, the County seat of Benton, now Calhoun County. He was a signer of the 1839 Cession Treaty and was made an allotment under that agreement.; A marker in the town square at Jacksonville is to his memory.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Tennessee Historical Society
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: Daniel Rice and James G. Clark

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: David Vann
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Portrait drawings; Portrait prints; Book illustrations
Cherokee; Indians of North America-- Biography; Indians of North America-- Portraits; Indians of North America-- History
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A half-length color portrait of David Vann, a Cherokee chief. The chief is dark-skinned, with curly hair. He is wearing a beaded sash.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: McKenney, Thomas Loraine, 1785-1859; Hall, James, 1793-1868
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: History of the Indian tribes of North America, with biographical sketches and anecdotes of the principal chiefs.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: David Vann was a Cherokee chief who prior to his removal had been conciliatory to the Unites States, signing a land cession treaty in 1806. During and after removal he aligned himself with Chief John Ross, who fought removal. After removal,; he served as Treasurer of the Nation in the 1840s, and helped establish the Cherokee female seminary.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Tennessee Historical Society
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: Daniel Rice and James G. Clark

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: John Ross
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Portrait drawings; Portrait prints; Indian agents; Book illustrations
Ross, John, 1790-1866; Cherokee; Indians of North America-- Biography; Indians of North America-- Portraits; Indians of North America-- History.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A half-length portrait, facing right, wearing a stylish suit and war paint. He is shown seated at a desk with letters on the desktop, to indicate the literacy of the Cherokee.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: McKenney, Thomas Loraine, 1785-1859; Hall, James, 1793-1868
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: History of the Indian tribes of North America, with biographical sketches and anecdotes of the principal chiefs.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: John Ross, born in Turkeytown, Alabama, October 3, 1790, and died in Washington, D.C., August 1, 1866, was the Principal Chief of the Cherokee from 1828 until his death. He was the first and only elected Chief of the Cherokee Nation from the time it was; formed until his death. He was highly regarded for his role in leading the fight against removal and leading the Cherokees to their exile in Oklahoma. The town John Ross founded as Rossville Landing was renamed Chattanooga, Tennessee.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Tennessee Historical Society
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: Daniel Rice and James G. Clark
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Apauly Tustennuggee
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Portrait drawings; Portrait prints; Indian agents; Book illustrations
Creeks; Indians of North America-- Biography; Indians of North America-- Portraits; Indians of North America-- History.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Head and shoulders portrait. He wears a yellow, striped jacket, red collar, white shirt, black cravat, silver necklace, patterned belt and silver headband, face paint and feathered headress.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: McKenney, Thomas Loraine, 1785-1859; Hall, James, 1793-1868
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: History of the Indian tribes of North America, with biographical sketches and anecdotes of the principal chiefs.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Creeks were a corn-growing people. Those that have been in the country some years, raised corn in large quantities; "some of the principal farmers crib from five to ten thusand bushels in a season." The Creeks are described as "a nation that is; proud, arrogant and haughty, brave and valiant in war." McKenny's brief description of Apauly Tustennuggee was "a chief and a warriorâ€¦a firm, brave man - and of good sense."
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Tennessee Historical Society
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: Daniel Rice and James G. Clark
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Sequoyah
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Portrait paintings; Headdresses; Medals; Pipes (Smoking); Alphabets (Writing systems)
Indians of North America -- Biography; Indians of North America -- Portraits; Indians of North America -- History
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Potrait of Sequoyah, credtited with inventing the Cherokee alphabet. Sequoyah is shown wearing a blue coat with a red and white headscarf and a peace medal hanging around his neck. He is pointing to a document showing the Cherokee alphabet and smoking a; pipe.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: McKenney, Thomas Loraine, 1785-1859; Hall, James, 1793-1868
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: History of the Indian tribes of North America, with biographical sketches and anecdotes of the principal chiefs.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Sequoyah (circa 1760-1843) was born in an Indian village near Fort Loudon on the Tennessee River. He served in a Cherokee regiment of the U. S. Army during the Creek War (1813-1814) and later removed to Arkansas. In 1821 he perfected an alphabet suitable; to the Cherokee language and returned to the eastern Cherokee homeland where he demonstrated and taught his invention. He then returned to Arkansas in 1823 to teach his alphabet to the western Cherokees.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Tennessee State Library & Archives
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Cherokee Alphabet
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Alphabets (Writing systems); Phonetic alphabets
Sequoyah, 1770?-1843; Phonetic Alphabet; Indians of North America -- History
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Example of the Cherokee alphabet showing the characters systematically arranged with the sounds.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: McKenney, Thomas Loraine, 1785-1859; Hall, James, 1793-1868
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: History of the Indian tribes of North America, with biographical sketches and anecdotes of the principal chiefs.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The creation of the Cherokee alphabet has historically been attributed to Sequoyah (aka George Guess) in the early 1820s. The syllabary consisted of eighty-six symbols representing seventy-nine consonant-vowel combinations, six vowels, and the consonant; /s/. While the alphabet seemingly symbolized an adoption of white civilization, it also indicated a preservation of Cherokee culture through the use of the syllabary.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Tennessee State Library & Archives
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: McIntosh
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Portrait paintings; Headdresses; Daggers & swords
Indians of North America -- Biography; Indians of North America -- Portraits; Indians of North America -- History
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Portrait of Creek chief William McIntosh wearing a cape over a checkered red vest and white shirt. His hand is on the hilt of a sword and his headdress is adorned with a single feather.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: McKenney, Thomas Loraine, 1785-1859; Hall, James, 1793-1868
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: History of the Indian tribes of North America, with biographical sketches and anecdotes of the principal chiefs.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: William McIntosh (or MacIntosh) was born in Georgia about 1785 of mixed ancestry, his father being a Scots trader and his mother a Creek Indian. He became a Creek chief at an early age and fought on the side of the Americans during the Creek War (1813-; 1814). His contiuned alliance with the U. S. government led to his death in 1825 by rival Creeks incensed at McIntosh's participation at the Indian Springs treaty which surrendred millions of acres to the Federal government.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Tennessee State Library & Archives
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Tah Chee
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Portrait paintings; Headdresses; Daggers & swords
Indians of North America -- Biography; Indians of North America -- Portraits; Indians of North America -- History
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Portrait of Cherokee chief Tah-Chee shown wearing a lavender tunic with a dagger tucked into a green sash belted around the waist. His headdress is topped with a large red feather.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: McKenney, Thomas Loraine, 1785-1859; Hall, James, 1793-1868
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: History of the Indian tribes of North America, with biographical sketches and anecdotes of the principal chiefs.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Tah-Chee (the Cherokee word for "Dutch") was born circa 1790 in present-day Alabama but became one of the earliest Cherokees to remove west of the Mississippi, settling south of the Arkansas River. He led a renegade band of Cherokees intent on resisting; Federal authority and warring on neighboring tribes, particularly the Osages. He later became a valuable guide and hunter for the government, eventually settling at the mouth of the Canadain River. He died in Oklahoma in 1848.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Tennessee State Library & Archives
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Major Ridge
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Portrait paintings
Indians of North America -- Biography; Indians of North America -- Portraits; Indians of North America -- History
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Portrait of Cherokee chief Major Ridge shown wearing a blue coat, brown vest, and white shirt.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: McKenney, Thomas Loraine, 1785-1859; Hall, James, 1793-1868
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: History of the Indian tribes of North America, with biographical sketches and anecdotes of the principal chiefs.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Major Ridge (circa 1771-1839) was a war chief of the Cherokees born at Hiwassee, now Polk County, Tennessee. He distinguished himself in the Creek War (1813-1814), organizing Cherokee volunteers to fight with Andrew Jackson against the Creeks. He rose in; prominence among the Cherokee nation, becoming Speaker of the Council in 1827. Ridge's power eventually waned after he sided with the Cherokee faction advocating removal west of the Mississippi, resulting in the infamous Trail of Tears.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Tennessee State Library & Archives
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Opothele-Yoholo
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Portrait paintings
Indians of North America -- Biography; Indians of North America -- Portraits; Indians of North America -- History
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Portrait of Creek Chief Opothele-Yoholo in colorful Native-American wear with feathers in his hat.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: McKenney, Thomas Loraine, 1785-1859; Hall, James, 1793-1868
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: History of the Indian tribes of North America, with biographical sketches and anecdotes of the principal chiefs.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Opothele-Yoholo was born at Tuckabatchee, Creek Nation (in Alabama), the son of a white father and a Native-American mother. He was an important figure in Creek political affairs; during the winter of 1824-1825, he opposed the sale of Creek land to the; government of Georgia. He resisted removal to the west, but in 1836, was nonetheless obligated to lead 15,000 of his people to the Indian Territory in the west. Opothele-Yoholo was also involved in Civil War battles against the Confederate forces.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Tennessee Historical Society
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Yoholo-Micco
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Portrait paintings
Indians of North America -- Biography; Indians of North America -- Portraits; Indians of North America -- History
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Portrait of Creek Chief Yoholo-Micco in colorful Native-American wear.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: McKenney, Thomas Loraine, 1785-1859; Hall, James, 1793-1868
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: History of the Indian tribes of North America, with biographical sketches and anecdotes of the principal chiefs.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: During the war of 1813-1814, Yoholo-Micco served with McIntosh against the opposing group of Native Americans. This Creek chief and orator was also a part of the Creek delegation to Washington in 1825-6 that objected to the Indian Springs treaty of 1821; Through this treaty, the Creeks had lost much of their land, but Yoholo-Micco was unable to get it back. Consequently, he participated in his village's removal from Alabama to Arkansas. He died when he was 50 years old.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Tennessee Historical Society
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Paddy Carr
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Portrait paintings
Indians of North America -- Biography; Indians of North America -- Portraits; Indians of North America -- History
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Portrait of Creek interpreter Paddy Carr in colorful Native-American wear.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: McKenney, Thomas Loraine, 1785-1859; Hall, James, 1793-1868
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: History of the Indian tribes of North America, with biographical sketches and anecdotes of the principal chiefs.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Paddy Carr was the son of an Irishman who had married a Creek woman. Born in Alabama, he early on showed proficiency in languages. He served as interpreter during the Creek delegation to Washington in 1826.; He was known to have had three wives as well as a passion for thoroughbred racehorses. Carr served as a leader of the Creek people throughout his lifetime.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Tennessee Historical Society
